instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.CD3251: What is CD3251? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3251 was most likely referring to CD3215.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
Hi,

This board has no signs of liquid damage. 

Charger was stuck at 5V 0amp. I had no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, found <CAPACITOR>C7078</CAPACITOR> was bad,  replaced it and now I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> again. Only it's stuck around 2.1V. 

I removed <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> (and replaced, just to be sure), and I have 3.3V on pin 1, so there shouldn't be an issue with my <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> I think? I figured it was <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<CHIP>ISL9232</CHIP>), replaced it, but  the problem remains the same. I do have 5V 0.05a on the charger at this point. So now I'm running in circles, I can't seem to figure out why I have this drop on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Diode mode reading (red on ground) on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.384. This is with <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> back on the board.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0.2V if that is any hint. Thank you in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

If you get 3V at <CAPACITOR>C6995</CAPACITOR> removing <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>, then the problem is on the right side of <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>.
Something consumes more current than expected.

Check diode mode to ground on LDO rails of both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Take a look at USB redriver chip, PI3USB32224.
It doesn't appear in the schematic, nor boardview; as many times explained on the forum.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
Thank you!

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> 0.506
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0.484
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0.524
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.519

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 0.505
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0.487
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0.526
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.521

Forgot to mention I temporarily removed the redriver chip, sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
Now post voltage for these lines.
Be aware, <SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> should only appear on the powered port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> 2.18v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.27v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 1.79v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0v

This is measured using one of the usb ports, should I do it as well with the second usb port?

A second question, don't know if it is relevant to this because I lost track of how I got there, but while checking around a bit I noticed <SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> are short to ground. I've noticed it is connected to pin 28 of the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> I replaced, right next to 2 ground pins. Should I assume I did not solder it properly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message: Yep, messed up the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>, removed it and the short was gone. I'm afraid I'm out of <CHIP>ISL9237</CHIP>'s, ordered one, should have it in 2 days. Am I correct in assuming this is the cause of the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
You must replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> correctly.
Bad solders, or accidental short will make you waste the time.

BTW, check <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip voltage when charger is connected to corresponding port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> dragged down to 2.1V
threads.message:
Sorry I didn't get back to you on the <CHIP>CD3251</CHIP> voltage.

But, I replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. After that, <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> turned out to be bad as well, replaced it, and have a fully working board now!

Thank you for the assistance! :)
